awd_titl_txt: ATD:   Collaborative Research:  Multivariate Quantiles for Rapid Spatio-Temporal Threat Detection
awd_abstract_narration:
Different kinds of data on societal attributes, observed from multiple sources, at multiple locations, and at different points in time, will be studied in this project. The geometrical properties of such data will be analyzed to quantify and characterize normal patterns in the data, which will then be leveraged to identify sudden departures from normal patterns within societies. Methodology for understanding normal patterns in the data and rapidly detecting change in one or more aspects of the data will be devised in this project. Data from different locations around the world will be analyzed and used to formulate strategies for risk mitigation and emergency responses.

The geometric properties of high-dimensional spatio-temporal data will be studied in this project to construct a multi-dimensional extremity indicator. This indicator and other statistical and machine learning techniques will be used for rapid spatio-temporal change detection, under a variety of technical conditions and frameworks. Such changes may be towards specific known directions, or generic departures from normal patterns. Methods for detecting changes in extremes and tails of multivariate probability distributions will likewise be developed as part of this project. Social, economic, and supply chain logistics data will then be studied to develop policy and rapid response strategies using data-driven techniques.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Over the duration of the project we have made significant progress in terms of developing methodologies for spatio-temporal data analysis, and high-dimensional data analysis. Furthermore, we have applied these methodologies in the context of primarily modeling, (i) conflict, climate and trade dynamics, and (ii) epidemiological modeling in estimating infectious disease transmission and diffusion over a graphical network of connected locations. Below we describe the accomplishments under each of the goals.

 

(Goal 1). Methods for analyzing spatial-temporal processes related to many different applications including the interaction of social, political and rebel related conflict, weather related variables, and weather related variables:

  1. 1.      We have completed seeral papers in this goal. 

 

  1. 2.      The main paper that we have completed develops a Bayesian spatio-temporal model has been used to model the effect of climate anomalies and conflict incidences. We have shown in the paper that climate anomalies (temperature anomalies) are significantly associated with both material conflict, which involves incidences of physical violence, as well as verbal conflict, which involves verbal arguments, protests and exchanges among different actors. 

 

The paper reference is:

Mukherjee, U.K., Bagozzi, B.E. and Chatterjee, S., 2022. A Bayesian framework for studying climate anomalies and social conflicts. Environmetrics, p.e2778.

The R code along with sample data for the Bayesian methodology is available at:

https://github.com/Ujjal-Mukherjee/Temperature-Anomaly-Conflict-Code

 

 

  1. 3.      Another paper that is in the working paper stage is related to the impact of conflict on global trade. Conflict and global trade in commodities, manufactured products and agricultural products have a complex relationship. 

 

(Goal 2) Develop a Kernel Projection Quantile Methodology for quantile estimation of high-dimensional datasets:

In the previous report and in the original goals submitted during the project initiation, we had mentioned about the Kernel Projection Quantile (KWPQ) methodology development for estimating quantile surfaces of high dimensional and large datasets. The algorithmic development is complete and we have a R package that we have developed for the quantile estimation. We have been testing the package extensively. Also, we are extending the core methodology to several secondary analysis techniques such as non-parametric quantile regression, and non-parametric local principal components. We are on target to complete the algorithmic development and the associated code (R package) in 2022.

The R/C++ code along with simulations for the package on KWPQ is available at:

https://github.com/Ujjal-Mukherjee/Quantiles

 

(Goal 3) Disruptions from unexpected events such as COVID-19 pandemic:

 We have extended the spatial and temporal methodological developments, and combined those with analytical modeling and simulation analysis to predict the diffusion of SARS-CoV-2 over a network of connected locations. Furthermore, COVID-19 exhibits significant latent transmission driven by the asymptomatic population and mobility over a network. Below, find a list of papers that we have published in this goal. We also hae several working papers getting ready for publication. 

Mukherjee, U.K. and Seshadri, S., 2022. Epidemic Modeling, Prediction, and Control. In Tutorials in Operations Research: Emerging and Impactful Topics in Operations (pp. 1-35). INFORMS.

Mitra, A.K., Mukherjee, U., Mazumder, S., Madhira, V., Bergquist, T., Shao, Y., Liu, F., Song, Q., Su, J., Bates, B. and Sharafeldin, N., 2022. Major risk factors associated with severe COVID-19 outcomes in patients with multiple myeloma: Report from the National COVID-19 Cohort Collaborative (N3C).

Bose, S., Souyris, S., Mukherjee, U.K., Ivanov, A., Seshadri, S., England, A.C. and Xu, Y., 2021, December. Control of epidemic spreads via testing and lock-down. In 2021 60th IEEE Conference on Decision and Control (CDC) (pp. 4272-4279). IEEE.

Souyris, S., Hao, S., Bose, S., England, A.C.I., Ivanov, A., Mukherjee, U.K. and Seshadri, S., 2022. Detecting and mitigating simultaneous waves of COVID-19 infections. Scientific reports, 12(1), p.16727.

Mukherjee, U.K., Bose, S., Ivanov, A., Souyris, S., Seshadri, S., Sridhar, P., Watkins, R. and Xu, Y., 2021. Evaluation of reopening strategies for educational institutions during COVID-19 through agent based simulation. Scientific Reports, 11(1), pp.1-24.  


[1] https://climatedataguide.ucar.edu/climate-data/global-surface-temperatures-best-berkeley-earth-surface-temperatures

[2] https://dataverse.harvard.edu/dataverse/icews

[3] https://microdata.worldbank.org/index.php/home

[4] https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SP.POP.TOTL

 


Last Modified: 05/16/2024
Modified by: Ujjal Mukherjee
